columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the operating and cash cycles and interpret the answer.
**Operating Cycle** refers to the days required for a business to make an initial outlay of cash to produce goods, sell the goods and collect cash from customers.

Operating Cycle is computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Operating Cycle} &= \text{Inventory Period} + {\text{Receivable Period}}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Let's identify the given amounts in the problem.


| | Beginning | |Ending | 
|--|--:|--:|--:| 
|Inventory | $ 11,718| |$ 14,865 | 
|Accounts Receivable |5,860 | |6,127 | 
|Accounts Payable | 7,930| | 8,930| 
|Credit Sales | |$ 127,382 | | 
|Cost of Goods Sold | |76,157 | |

First, let's identify the inventory period. To begin, we will calculate the inventory turnover by dividing the cost of goods sold and average inventory.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Inventory Turnover} &= \dfrac{\text{Cost of Goods Sold}}{\frac{\text{Beg. Inventory + End. Inventory}}{2}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 76,157}}{\frac{\text{\$ 11,718 + 14,865 }}{2}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 76,157}}{{\text{\$ 13,291.50 }}}\\[10pt]
&=\underline{\underline{\text{ 5.7298 times}}}
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we can now compute the inventory period by dividing 365 days by the inventory turnover. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Inventory Period} &= \dfrac{\text{365 days}}{\text{Inventory Turnover}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{365 days}}{\text{5.7298}}\\[10pt]
&=\underline{\underline{\text{ 63.70 days}}}
\end{aligned}$$


As can be seen, the inventory period is 63.70 days.

Next, we will identify the receivable period but before that let's calculate first the receivable turnover by dividing the credit sales by the average accounts receivables. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Receivable Turnover} &= \dfrac{\text{Credit Sales}}{\frac{\text{Beg. AR+ End. AR}}{2}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 127,382}}{\frac{\text{\$ 5,860 + 6,127}}{2}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 127,382}}{{\text{\$ 5,993.50}}}\\[10pt]
&=\underline{\underline{\text{ 21.2534 times}}}
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we can now compute the inventory period by dividing 365 days by the inventory turnover. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Receivable Period} &= \dfrac{\text{365 days}}{\text{Receivable Turnover}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{365 days}}{\text{21.2534 }}\\[10pt]
&=\underline{\underline{\text{ 17.17 days}}}
\end{aligned}$$


As can be seen, the receivable period is 17.17 days.

Now that we have computed the inventory and receivable period, let's now determine the operating cycle using equation in step 3.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Operating Cycle} &= \text{Inventory Period} + {\text{Receivable Period}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{63.70 days} + {\text{17.17 days}}\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\textbf{80.88 days}}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen, the **operating cycle** of the company is **80.88 days**.
**Cash Cycle** measure the days from paying the suppliers for inventory to collecting the cash from sale of goods.

Cash Cycle is computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Cycle} &= \text{Operating Cycle} - {\text{Payable Period}}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

First, let's identify the payable period.  To begin, we will calculate the payable turnover by dividing the cost of goods sold and average accounts payable.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Payable Turnover} &= \dfrac{\text{Cost of Goods Sold}}{\frac{\text{Beg. AP + End. AP}}{2}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 76,157}}{\frac{\text{\$ 7,930 + 8,930}}{2}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 76,157}}{{\text{\$ 8,430}}}\\[10pt]
&=\underline{\underline{\text{ 9.0340 times}}}
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we can now compute the payable period by dividing 365 days by the payable turnover. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Payable Period} &= \dfrac{\text{365 days}}{\text{Payable Turnover}}\\[10pt]
 &= \dfrac{\text{365 days}}{\text{9.0340 }}\\[10pt]
&=\underline{\underline{\text{ 40.40 days}}}
\end{aligned}$$


As can be seen, the payable period is 40.40 days.

Now that we have already computed the operating cycle and payable  period, let's now determine the cash cycle using equation in step 11.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Cycle} &= \text{Operating Cycle} - {\text{Payable Period}}\\[5pt]
 &= \text{80.88 days} - {\text{40.40 days}}\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\textbf{40.48 days}}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen, the **cash cycle** of the company is **40.48 days**.

In conclusion, the operating cycle of the Newk Corporation is **80.88 days**, and it represents the number of days taken solely in selling inventories. On the other hand, Newk corporation receives cash on an average of **40.48 days** after paying their debt obligation.
